title: Robinson Preserve Sport Fish
section: Tracking the movement of juvenile sport fish from a habitat restoration site to fished populations of Tampa Bay
text:
Tracking the movement of juvenile sport fish from a habitat restoration site to fished populations of Tampa Bay
Many commercially and recreationally important fishes use estuarine habitats as juvenile nursery grounds. However, many of these habitats are threatened by a number of stressors, including rising sea levels and increasing urbanization. Restoration and preservation of affected juvenile habitats can help support adult populations.
The Robinson Preserve Sport Fish Tagging Project was initiated to determine the extent to which the habitat restoration at Robinson Preserve, a 682-acre area with a variety of restored fisheries nursery habitat, contributes juvenile sport fish to adult populations in the greater Tampa Bay area. The contribution of juveniles is a major information gap that exists for many habitat restoration projects, despite being a realistic metric for evaluating restoration success. With the help of Manatee County Department of Parks and Natural Resources and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Office of Habitat Conservation, researchers at the Florida Fish and Wildlife Research Institute are seeking to fill this information gap by tagging and tracking the movement of juvenile sport fishes from and within Robinson Preserve.

title: Welcome
text: Welcome to our website! In this Project Updates section, we will provide information on the latest progress our research team has made towards assessing juvenile contributions from Robinson Preserve to Tampa Bay adult populations. Stay tuned!

Receiver Deployment





On April 18th, 2022, 13 acoustic receivers were deployed at various locations around Robinson Preserve to monitor the movement of juvenile sport fishes within and out of the preserve area.

title: Robinson Preserve Sport Fish
section: Tracking juvenile sport fish movement from a habitat restoration site to fished populations of Tampa Bay
text:
Tracking juvenile sport fish movement from a habitat restoration site to fished populations of Tampa Bay
Many commercially and recreationally important fishes use estuarine habitats as juvenile nursery grounds. However, many of these habitats are threatened by a number of stressors, including rising sea levels and increasing urbanization. Restoration and preservation of affected juvenile habitats can help support adult populations.






The Robinson Preserve Sport Fish Tagging Project was initiated to determine the extent to which the habitat restoration at Robinson Preserve, a 682-acre area with a variety of restored fisheries nursery habitat, contributes juvenile sport fish to adult populations in the greater Tampa Bay area. The contribution of juveniles is a major information gap that exists for many habitat restoration projects, despite being a realistic metric for evaluating restoration success. With the help of Manatee County Department of Parks and Natural Resources and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Office of Habitat Conservation, researchers at the Florida Fish and Wildlife Research Institute are seeking to fill this information gap by tagging and tracking the movement of juvenile sport fishes from and within Robinson Preserve.

title: Receiver Deployment
text: On April 18th, 2022, 13 acoustic receivers were deployed at various locations around Robinson Preserve to monitor the movement of juvenile sport fishes within and out of the preserve area.

title: Contact
text: Questions and comments about the project or the website can be sent to Meagan Schrandt. All source content for the website can be viewed on Github. All data were obtained through the FWC Fish and Wildlife Research Institute in collaboration with Manatee County and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
